title: Funding the Cooperative City
segmentation: I'm going to speak about this book we published recently, and the research related to that.
But before that I would like to ask how many of you have a bank account.
OK, quite good you don't.
How many of you know what's happening with your money?
How is your money used in this bank?
Two people so we are about 4%, so you probably you, probably members of an ethical bank that at least has what they don't use your money for.
So they probably don't buy.
They don't finance weapons, they don't finance wars all over us.
But I also have a bank account there, but all the rest, you might be surprised to learn what your money is used for.
It might be for four wars, but at best it's very often finances.
This kind of stuff OK. And I think some things that's really important today.
Yesterday we spoke a little bit about what's the difference between can we move social housing into these kinds of buildings?
In theory we can because you know, there space, we can move people in, But was the big difference is not so much form.
It's really about what kind of money is behind.
Yesterday we spoke about the Grenfell Tower.
Grenfell Tower didn't start burning because because the bed architecture it was started burning because of the bed maintenance program, mostly because of the austerity politics, but also because.
Because the ownership structure behind.

If you think of the protagon or the famous the iconic complex that we learned that modernism died when they exploded the Pruitt IGO complex, it actually didn't go down because the architecture was bad.
He went down because because the subsidies disappeared from the whole funding program.
So you have the same architecture that can work and you can say market.
It doesn't work when there's different kinds of money behind the same thing in Spain.
In the recent years now.
Entire movements were born because people were evicted, not because the architecture was bad.
It's because the kind of money that was behind it needed different kinds of conditions.
Now some money very much intervenes in how we use our existing spaces.
It also produces a lot of new forms we all know about how architecture has become a tool of speculation.
It also.
For example, if you go to war, so there's very absolute process that's happening now.

In the restitution process, people are reclaiming land that they owned before the war, which was practically all erased, and now of course the whole city has a very different zoning plan, so people are going back and reclaiming land and evicting people because they have actually re situated their land before the war, and they're building the skyscrapers again.
So there's a funny kind of Commerce with the land again, the money behind the land, which changes completely the dynamics.
Or you have tourism as we heard in the case of Portal which again produces new forms of architecture.
Now I learned in portal when I was there last time that traditional typology's are dying out because everybody is designing.
Now everybody is renovating and changing their apartment into into into apartments that are there are more rented before NB, NB, NB.
So we have a lot of pressure from different sides that are through which money and money that is looking.
In the case of the Airbnb as we saw yesterday and we work we live.
Looking into fragmenting space and time to the to the smallest possible and maximizing profit to the highest possible as well.
So this is what we this is.
All these things that we do actually has been done with our money.
Like if I go to Lisbon for example.
Here we are in Lisbon.
It's quite likely that most of the people would go to Airbnb because this is the cheapest option.
This is again a choice that puts a lot of pressure on the local housing estate, the housing market.
So again all our choices.
All the.
Ways we use money is a very important have very important consequences Now, architecture.
And architects have been very complicit in all this.
But there's a lot of different ways we could we could think about all this.
Especially because if we think about, well, I'll get back to this later about how we use our money, actually.
So a little bit what comarca?
Things do traditionally.
You know we we if I could if I count myself as an architect, which I'm not really.
We help a lot.
Communities accessing space.
This is for example a program we did in Budapest helping a lot of NGOs existing space.

This is a circus school which was looking for a very specific, very high space because for circus you need very high space is very unique so we need an overview of what's available in the city we need.
We need transparency, we need an understanding of the real estate stock.
Thanks can also like we did again with our organization in Budapest.
Can mobilize knowledge and resources like in the case of this community garden where which has become an important point of exchange with very little very little actually physical intervention.
But again architecture gives the pretext to bring together all these people.
We can also help communities secure and safe community spaces, like in Rome, where this is a big occupied industrial area which we're trying to help to buy the area to stay.
Well, a lot of new actors, financial actors who can maybe contribute to this kind of mechanism and we will go back to the question that was discussed before the break.
But how can we finance this kind of venture?
Also architecture.
Can be very important to build connections like through agencies like this one.
Vienna, which is like a neighborhood quarters management agency which mostly run by architects.
But it brings together people in the neighborhood with very specific questions about renovations etc etc.
But we can go a little bit beyond this.
We can think of architecture and the related disciplines as.
As actors that can also alter the economic, the underlying economic structures.

Now we're in Berlin right now in extra print, which was one of the pilot projects of an artist community buying space with the help of an anti Speculation Foundation which means that the foundation comes in buys the length.
The community takes a loan to buy the building.
They repay the loan from renting out the spaces and they.
Pay a regular fee to the foundation that money goes into Solidarity Fund that feeds new projects like this.
They will never be able to make money out of this more than using the space because the whole legal setup is composed in a way that you cannot sell.
You cannot speculate with the space.
You cannot sell the space again because this is against the whole whole point of departure.
Or you can design new models of ownership, like in the case of Community land trusts, quite much spreading in.
UK also entering and continental Europe with the new Community Land Trust growing in Belgium in France.
Where the whole idea is that land is owned by a community, buildings can be on individually, but the community ownership defines the ways you can actually sell again your your building or your space.
There's also it's also defined.
How can you use it?
And there's a defined cap that how much you can sell it for more for than you bought it.
So there is again in the legal arrangement there is a coded protection of the real estate from speculation, or you can design new models of governance.
When for example, like in Turin, where where you have it's.
Public civic run big space.

A former farmhouse in the outskirts of Turin, where practically there's a board of directors constituting over 150 associations, plus some people of the municipality and decision-making, is done together in a shared way.
Or you can.
You can start looking as an architect started thinking of buildings.
How can you put them?
In the middle of local economic circuits like we did a lot trying to rethink public infrastructure like markets like you know nearly dying in markets in the middle of Rome or in other cities as well.
How can we?
How can we think new users?
How can we connect existing economic circuits in some buildings?
And I forget this slide, but it's also something that I really really like.
For example, Speaking of travel and Speaking of choice is how we spend our money.
For example, when we go to Lisbon, we go to this one alot.
We usually stay in the place.
The only place that I know in Europe that is a cooperative socially responsible Hostel hotel that uses all the revenues for to reach analysis into local economy.
Don't get me wrong, I love hotel Lev.
It's really comfortabl is great.
I don't know where my money goes.
It probably goes into an international company.
OK for now can we use remove a lot of people?
You do.
I move a lot.
We all move a lot of people.
Can we use all this money in a different way?
I think we can.
So what can architects do with all this?
On the one hand, we heard yesterday that I really like.
Quote That the world is too complex for architects as a special group to be able to offer solutions for everything.
Which is true, but I think also the world.

Well, I think architects have many ways to support these projects because many of these spaces need actually very very specific architectural knowledge and more importantly, what can we do with our money?

For example, a few months ago there was a crowdfunding campaign in Barcelona for social housing Laborda, which meant that if you had 1000 euro you, you couldn't enter this one with lower amount, but in many cases you can enter with a lower amount.

If you had 1000 Euro, you could invest this into this social housing on the land offered by the city of Barcelona, and they guaranteed you 2% return on your interest and after three years the return of your own money.
This is helping a social housing that is very scarce in Barcelona.
Again, when I have my money and you have your money in your bank, you get 0.01.
Percent of interest properly and you spend much more with the you know the OR the administration costs.
In this case you get back 2% of your money.
So there are ways to find in social projects.
We just have to find the right constellations, the right format, 'cause there's a lot of money around that is looking into as you as you mentioned, looking into looking for investment for example.
Athens no.
The whole austerity measures the hope EU pressure on Athens is forcing Greece to sell very important assets.
I'm not saying that we should make a crowd funding to buy the Port of Heroes.
I think it's too late, but we could make a crowd funding to buy a lot of buildings that are being sold for nothing right now.
And we could.
We could.
We could invent business models that would be community friendly, socially responsible.
And you know, with all European crowd sourced money could actually provide decent community services for.
For the Greek people or for tourists who want to spend their money in a responsible way.
Now, this is what we've been doing in the last few months and few years.
Actually, looking into different ways where where this kind of economic thinking can be.

By then, we realized that it's not only housing, of course, housing is at the forefront of experimentation, but there's all kinds of spaces that are being built, being being renovated, being purchased, being being properties across Europe, and this makes an entire city if we want.
If we want to.
So in the last few years we did a lot of workshops, we.
Actually, when
Around with this book or signal last few months, which is quite an interesting experience.
Maybe I start the video because I'm running out of time.
And maybe I take off the OK. We don't have sound, So what?
We tried in the last month is to to bring this collection of ideas and examples around in Europe to test a little bit.
What kind of idea resonates in different contexts.
And of course we realize that.
On the one hand, we have.
Well, different regions in Europe have very different relationships to money, to ownership to relationship with the public administration.
So for us this was actually really interesting learning process about different values, different ideas of of money and what communities are capable of.
Sometimes I think it's about religion, but I hope I hope it's not.
And maybe because yesterday we also spoke about some jealousy towards the 1920s radical projects.
That that that were I don't know, maybe very courageous, very appealing.
I think we have a lot of radical projects today and these are the radical projections today.
They're not radical inform.
They're radical in in the set up their radical in the organizational structure.
Their radical in their ownership structure just the way they were actually in the Soviet in the Soviet Union in the 20s.
So.
What's what are we doing now?
We're going around a bit and we work.
We are invited.

Sometimes by municipalities, sometimes by local organizations well in the cities where we are present, Budapest and Rome and little bit in Vienna we do work with local organizations and we help them to elaborate their own financial plans.
We bring in some of the ethical financial actors that we met on this road, so we try to implement all this locali and also we do a lot of advocacy work related to this issues.
For example, how can we have?
Can we think of some of these German or Swiss anti speculation foundations?
How could they work for example across the borders?
How could they come and bring their capital in Italy?
How can for example in Portugal where there's a lot of scarcity of capital, but in Spain very near there's you know financial cooperatives that are actually maybe willing to jump in.
How can we think international about all these sources of money for real estate development projects and also on another level?
How can we think?
About European public money.

In a way that it should be channeled actually into community about Community wise, relevant real estate development projects and in the end maybe a little bit responding to to what we discussed before the break.
How can we make sense of real estate?
No real estate itself is not good or bad like money itself is not good or bad.
It really depends on how we think about real estate and money to make sense of this.
So all the book is online.
You can find this and vary with.
With good chances, you might also find it in your nearest libraries.
